DOC.HEAD: Boeing Engineers Pressed Into Service As Santa's Helpers
DOC.TEXT: Youngsters calling Santa Claus over the past week may have been thinking of his sleigh and eight tiny reindeer, but they got the people who keep 530-mph, four-engine military radar reconnaissance jets in the air. And most of them will never know they got the wrong number. The children got connected to technicians at Boeing's support center for specially equipped military aircraft. ``This was quite a surprise when it started out,'' said Duane Oberg, developer with the Airborne Warning and Control System, or AWACS, fleet support system. ``But after the first several calls we figured out what had happened, and just started answering phones as if this was Santa's workshops.'' Hundreds of children got their lines crossed because of transposed numbers in a telephone listing in a national magazine, Boeing Aerospace & Electronics spokesman Elliot Pulham said Wednesday. The aerospace branch of Boeing specializes in missiles, spacecraft and spy airplanes _ for some, the ultimate toys. He said the calls began about Dec. 13 and were winding down by the middle of this week, after calls for Santa were redirected. The first youngsters might have been greeted with, ``Hi. This is AWACS Fleet Support Central. Can I help you?'' Pulham said. But the engineers lightened up and played along. ``They were putting on their bonnets, and would play Santa whenever the children would call, but they would give technical information when customers called,'' he said. The normal phone calls to the center are for technical assistance provided for those who fly, service and repair the AWACS aircraft, which are loaded with sophisticated radar and other surveillance equipment. There are only 60 such aircraft in operation built by Boeing, Pulham said, and the toll-free phone line is normally not busy. The engineers didn't mind the distractions. ``It was actually kind of fun,'' Oberg said. ``Definitely a break from what we normally do. Although I think some of our customers were a bit surprised when they called for radar or computer information and ended up talking to Santa's workshop.'' Pulham said the situation didn't get out of hand, no matter what the children might have asked for. ``We didn't promise anybody any cruise missiles or anything like that for Christmas,'' he said.
